problems.title: SAS 1.1 Solving a Mystery with Proportional Reasoning

text: The introduction to this Problem can be used to assess students’ initial ideas about the concept of scaled drawings/similarity. The P.I. Mystery Club enters a contest to guess the identity of a teacher in disguise. A photo of the mystery teacher is shown, and students use a known measure (height of a magazine) to estimate an unknown measure (height of the mystery teacher). Students are asked to express their informal ideas about the mathematical meaning of similarity.

Note: The word similar is not defined in the Student Edition yet. Students are formulating their own working definition of mathematical similarity. Scaled drawings and the concept of similarity are used to set the backdrop for the students’ work in 7th grade on proportional reasoning. The words scaled drawings and similarity can be used interchangeably at this point for students. Students’ understanding will develop throughout the Unit and is revisited in each of the Mathematical Reflections. Students will take this understanding into 8th grade where they will study similarity more formally as they study what happens to congruent and similar figures under transformations in the Flip, Spin, Slide, and Stretch Unit.
Build off the common language of “similar” to informally introduce the idea of two figures being mathematically similar.
Apply knowledge of ratios and begin to recognize proportional relationships between quantities to estimate length of enlarged figure.
The Mystery Club advisor says that the picture is similar to the actual scene. What do you suppose the advisor means by similar? How is the photo similar to the actual scene that is photographed?

Students began their work in proportional reasoning in 6th grade. They have used “for every” statements in many situations. Have them recall some of that work. Examples from Comparing Quantities: for every $3 the Washington students plan to raise the Central students plan to raise $1; for every 10 students who prefer cheese, five students prefer pepperoni; for every 30 Chewy Fruit worms it costs $30. In this problem students will expand their thinking around “for every” statements using similar figures are also called scale drawings or scale figures. This will lay a foundation for future work on proportional reasoning.

This animation depicts members of the Mystery Club describing the contest and looking for clues to help them identify the mystery teacher. One student shows a photo she snapped of the teacher in disguise. The video prompts students to think about what information the photo gives them about the mystery teacher. You can show students this animation before discussing the introduction to the Problem. Display Learning Aid 1.1: Photograph of Mystery Teacher or have the students refer to their books.

• What information do we have? (the height of the real-life magazines, the height of the magazines in the photo, and the height of the teacher in the photo)
  • What are we trying to find? (the real-life height of the teacher)
  • How does the real-life teacher differ from the teacher in the photo? (in the height and width; the real-life teacher is taller and wider)

Be careful to leave the task of finding the teacher’s height open enough so that you can learn what your students think about similar figures. Eliciting explicit strategies for finding the teacher’s height too soon could reduce your opportunity to assess your students’ thinking.

Students can use rulers or edges of a piece of paper to make informal estimates of various measurements. Do not push for precise measurement at this time. Pay attention, though, to which students measure naturally and easily and which struggle with measurement. This will help you to plan your teaching in later Problems in the Unit where careful measurement is important. Agency, Identity, Ownership)
What evidence will you use in the Summary to clarify and deepen understanding of the Now What Do You Know Question(s)? What will you do if you do not have evidence?
The Mystery Club Advisor says that the picture is similar to the actual scene. What do you suppose the advisor means by similar? How is the photo similar to the actual scene that is photographed?

Look for language such as ratio, rates, fractions, percentage, more than, or less than as students express their comparisons. In the Summarize you can come back to the comparisons and ask students to describe them using terms they learned in previous grades. This is a good assessment of what understanding students bring from Grade 6 about ratios, rational numbers and proportional reasoning. (Language)

Have students share their strategies and solutions on the height of the teacher. It is helpful for students to hear others’ ideas while they are developing their own. You should expect some variation in the answers because all measurements are approximations. However, answers that are obviously unreasonable should be examined closely and efforts should be made to figure out why they are incorrect.

• What would you expect the range of possible heights for the mystery teacher to be? If an answer is over 7 ft, is that reasonable? What about an answer of under 4 ft? (The teacher is about 72.5 in. or 6 ft 1/2 in. tall.)

• The magazine is 10 inches tall. The teacher is 7 magazines. They may use this and write a multiplication sentence: 7 x 10 = 70 inches tall or they might use a ratio of 1:7 and then scale up each ratio by 10.
  • In the picture, the height of the P. I. Monthly is 0.5 in. We know that the height of the real magazine is 10 in. So, the real magazine is 10 ÷ 0.5 = 2 times larger than in the picture. The teacher should also be 20 times larger in real life than he/she is in the picture. The teacher’s height in the picture is about 3 5/8 in. So, the actual height is about 20 x (3 5/8) =72 in.
  • Students may use ratio or “for every” statements, such as “The ratio of the teacher’s height in the picture to her height in real life is about 1 to 20.” or “For every inch in height of the magazine in the picture, there are 20 inches in height for the real magazine.”
  • Students may also compare the magazine in the picture to the teacher in the picture. In this case, the teacher is 3 5/8 ÷ 1/2 = 7 1/4 times as tall as the magazine. Students may say that the teacher is 7 1/4 magazines tall. This should be true in real life as well. Since the height of the magazine is 10 in., the teacher is 10 x 7 1/4 = 72.5 in. tall.
  • Some students will measure the height of both the magazine and of the mystery teacher in inches. They will then divide the height of the teacher by the height of the magazine to find how many magazines tall the teacher is. This is a more precise version of the first strategy. Make sure students are clear about the comparisons that they are making. They may compare the real magazine to the magazine in the picture or the magazine in the picture to the teacher in the picture.
  • If a video projector, electronic whiteboard, or document camera is available in the classroom, students might suggest projecting the image at full scale, zooming in or out until the P.I. Monthly magazine’s height is about 10 inches on the screen. This would also work if the magazine could be projected at 50% of full scale, so that its height is 5 inches on the screen.
Discuss students’ perception of similar figures/scaled drawings. They might say things like, “look alike,” “same shape,” “same features,” “different size,”... (Language)

When asked what the Mystery Club advisor means by “similar,” students may say that the figures in the picture look the same as the original shapes except in size. They may notice that the objects in the picture have the same shape as the actual objects.

• Can you think of some other times when you might want to use a photograph to estimate the size of something? (Answers will vary. Possible answers: You might want to use a photograph to estimate the size of a large item you plan to buy, such as a large bookshelf. Estimating its size can help you determine whether or not it will fit in its designated spot. You could also take a close-up shot of something small, like an insect, next to an object with a standard size, like a penny. Then you can compare features of the insect, such as its size, to pictures in a reference book.)
  • In the movie theater, the image of the person on screen is taller than the real person. How can you use the same techniques to estimate someone’s height from their image on a movie screen? (Answers will vary. Possible answer: If you know the actual measurement of an object in the image, you can use any of the strategies mentioned earlier to find the person’s actual height.)
  • Would you have been able to solve the problem had you not known the magazine was 10 inches tall? (Answers will vary. Possible answer: Yes. I could have measured the height of the actual bookshelf shown in the picture and used that height instead of the height of the magazine.)

Focus the summary conversations on the use of ratios, “for every” statements and measurement. Listen for the use of formal and informal language to assess your students’ understanding of these ideas to help you in your instruction for the rest of the Unit.
• What measurements were important to you in finding the height of the teacher? (height of the magazine in the picture, height of the magazine in real life, height of the teacher in the picture.)
Revisit the questions from the What If:

• In What If Situation A, do you agree with Daphne’s reasoning? (Yes. Guide the conversation around the reasoning that the teacher being 7 inches tall and each magazine being 10 inches in real life gives us 7 groups of 10.)
  • Can someone explain Daphne’s statement: For every one magazine height, there are 10 inches in real life? (Answers will vary. Listen for their current understanding about rates and unit rates so you can expand on this throughout the Unit.)

Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know questions. This might be a good time to talk about how similarity used in everyday life is different than how it used in mathematics.
Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.
• What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know Question?

1. Where did my students get stuck?
  2. What strategies did they use?
  3. What breakthroughs did my students have today?

• How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?
  • Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this Unit? The next Unit?

problems.title: SAS 1.2 Designing a Poster Using a Rubber Band Stretcher

text: The Problem begins with the Mystery Club enlarging a flier into a poster to attract new members. In this context, students create a similar figure using rubber bands. They make a stretcher by tying two rubber bands together and use it to enlarge two different figures. They compare how the general shape, line lengths, areas, perimeters, and angles are affected. This focuses students’ attention on the preservation of shape in similar figures
Informally explore enlarging a geometric figure and begin to notice which attributes change and which stay the same:

• angles of the two figures appear to be the same
  • side lengths of the enlarged figure are longer
  • area of the enlarged figure is bigger

The original figure and its image are similar figures. The image is also called the scale drawing of the original figure. For two similar figures, what characteristics and measures are the same? Different? Explain how you know.

In launching this Problem, your goal is to understand what your students intuitively know about scaled drawings or similar figures. Since CCSS does not mention similarity or scale drawings in prior grades, students’ understanding will likely be based on the use of “similarity” in everyday situations. In addition, you will want to assess their measurement skills.

Members of the Mystery Club want to make a poster that shows their logo. To do this, they need to enlarge the logo on the flyer they designed. Briefly discuss with students the desire to make a larger version of the original picture. Then tell them that you are going to demonstrate one method for doing so.

You will need to demonstrate how to draw a figure using a rubber band stretcher, using a marker either on the board or on chart paper taped to the wall. Test your setup before class so you know everything works. Place the anchor point so that the enlarged drawing will not overlap the original. Choose a figure to enlarge that your students will find interesting, such as a popular cartoon character, a logo, a smiley face, or a ghost. Some teachers make a stretcher with larger rubber bands to make it easier for students to see what the teacher is doing at the board.
• I have a super machine called a stretcher that will help me draw a copy of this figure. My machine has two parts. Watch me carefully while I make a stretcher before your very eyes!

Tie the two rubber bands together by passing one band through the other and back through itself. Pull on the two ends, moving the knot to the center of the bands. You may need to pull on the knot so that each band forms half of the knot.
Hold your finished stretcher in the air and demonstrate its stretch. Then, use it to draw a copy of the figure as you describe the process.

• Notice that I put one end of my stretcher on a point, called the anchor point, and hold it down securely without covering up any more of the band than necessary. I put the marker through the other end and stretch the bands until the knot is just above part of my figure. I move my marker as I trace the figure with the knot. I try to keep the knot directly over the original figure as my marker draws the new figure. I do not look at the marker as I draw. I only watch the knot. The more carefully the knot traces the original, the better my drawing will be.

Finish the drawing and ask students to describe the results. They will probably say the two figures look alike but that the new one is larger. Until they have made their own drawings, you do not need to press for more specific observations or relationships.

Distribute two rubber bands, a blank sheet of paper, and Learning Aid 1.2A: Right-handed version or Learning Aid 1.2B: Left-handed version to each student. Have students tape the two sheets to their desks using masking tape as shown below and in the Student Edition. Left-handed students will have the anchor point to their right and the blank sheet of paper to their left.

Let the students make their stretchers. Some students will have a hard time tying the bands together and will need assistance. You may want to be sure everyone has made a stretcher before the class begins drawing.
As students work, suggest that their drawings will be more accurate if they hold the pencil vertically and keep the rubber band as close to the point of the pencil as possible.

Remind students to trace the figure they are trying to copy with the knot, as they may be tempted to draw the object freehand. Accuracy is not the issue here, but students can get better drawings by being careful with the placement of the rubber bands on the pencil and the path of the knot on the figure.

A stretcher made from two rubber bands gives a figure enlarged by a factor of 2. This means the new length measures are twice as large as the original. Students may guess different factors for the growth of the lengths, which is fine at this stage, but they should be reasonably close to 2. In any case, this process is not very precise. Student error as well as variation in the length and stretchiness of the rubber bands will result in images that are not exactly twice as large.

Look for language such as ratio, rates, fractions, percentage, more than, or less than as students express their comparisons. In the Summarize you can come back to the comparisons and ask students to describe them using terms they learned in previous grades. This is a good assessment of what understanding students bring from Grade 6 about ratios and rational numbers. Paying particular attention to What If Situation A will give you information on students emerging understanding of proportional reasoning.
Transparent grids may be a helpful visual aid for some students to compare lengths of sides, perimeters, or areas of the figures. You may want to have them available throughout this Unit.
For What If Situation A, some students may benefit from the circle and square drawings that are in the ACE problems.

• What would happen if I made a three-band stretcher? (Notice that with a three-band stretcher there are two knots. The size change is different based on whether you use the knot closer to the anchor point (3 times larger) or the knot closer to the pencil (1.5 times larger).)
  • Do I get exactly the same drawing if I switch the ends of my two-band stretcher? (No. It is rarely the case that the two rubber bands are exactly alike in stretchiness and length. Furthermore, it is very difficult to get the bands to contribute equally to the knot. The net result is usually that the image is a bit more (less) than twice as large as the original in length. Switching the ends of the rubber band will then make the image a bit less (more) than twice as large.)
  • How could we use something like the rubber band stretcher to make an image smaller than the original? (This is a bit tricky, but possible to imagine. The standard stretcher method uses the knot to trace the smaller original and the end of the stretcher to trace the larger image. To shrink a figure, we need to switch the roles of the knot and the end. We would need to put a pencil at the knot and use the end of the stretcher to trace the original and have a friend or third hand to help.)
What evidence will you use in the Summary to clarify and deepen understanding of the Now What Do You Know? What will you do if you do not have evidence?

The original figure and its image are similar figures. The image is also called the scale drawing of the original figure. For two similar figures, what characteristics and measures are the same? Different? Explain how you know.

As you are observing students working with the rubber band stretchers and comparing their drawings to the originals listen to how they are describing them. Students will worry about the drawing being “perfect”. Help them to focus on the mathematical changes from the original shape to the image they are creating. How do they describe the change in the lengths of the line segments? The areas? Have they noticed that the angle measures stay the same? Take note of students who have ways to describe what has changed and what stayed the same so you can have them share this in the Summary discussion. (Agency, Identity, Ownership)
Have students share their findings about the image of the new figure as compared to the original figure.

Students will focus on their drawings, which aren’t perfect. The Summary needs to focus them back onto the mathematics around the use of the super stretcher. Discuss the Comparisons in What If Situation A.

• How do the lengths of the line segments compare between the two figures? (The image’s line segments are twice as long.)
  • How do the angles of the two figures compare? (They didn’t change.)
  • Which comparison statements in What If Situation A can be written as ratio statements? (Comparison 1—1:2 for original side length to image side length. Comparison 4—1:1/4 for original area to image area)

Blank transparency film is helpful in showing how the angles compare. Copy one angle of a figure and then place it on top of the corresponding angle of the second figure. Or have both figures on transparencies and place one on top of the other.

• How does the area change from the original to the image? (Students can informally compare the areas. They may use transparent grids or show informally how four of the smaller figures cover the larger figure. Or they may focus on the hat, which has a rectangular shape.)
  • The original and the image are similar figures. What do you think “mathematically similar” means? (Answers will vary.)
What do you think would happen to the original if we used a stretcher made of three rubber bands? (If we connect three rubber bands and use the first knot, we get an image that is 3 times as large.
If we use the second knot, we get an image that is 1.5 times as large.)

• the idea of the rubber bands being multipliers and
  • the ratio of 1:3 of the side lengths of the original to the side lengths of the image.

Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know questions. Help students to describe the changes in the side lengths and perimeter using “for every” statements or ratios. Help them to verbalize that the general shape is the same and that the angles don’t change as you change the original to its image.
Have students share their drawings from Situation B.
• When you used the super stretcher on a different figure, what comparisons from Situation A are still true? (The same ones that were true when the logo was stretched using the super stretcher.)
Have students share what they found with they changed the Anchor Point in Situation B.
Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.
• What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know?

1. Where did my students get stuck?
  2. What strategies did they use?
  3. What breakthroughs did my students have today?

• How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?
  • Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this Unit? The next Unit?

problems.title: SAS 1.3 Scaling Up and Down with Percents

text: In this Problem, using the context of a copy machine, students work with figures of various sizes that are similar to an original figure. They will work with some scale drawings that are smaller than the original figure and some that are larger. They will use percents to compare similar figures. They will compare side lengths and angles of similar figures and notice that lengths of sides may differ, but the measures of angles do not.
Continue exploring enlargements and reduction of geometric figures, working to understand what attributes change and what attributes stay the same and by how much (the multiplier).
When exploring a set of geometric figures: original, an enlargement and a reduction, begin to use and articulate relationships between attributes, such as:

• corresponding angles of an enlargement or reduction of an original figure stay the same
  • side lengths of an enlargement or reduction figure, as compared to the original figure, change in size by the multiplier used with the original
  • perimeter of an enlargement or reduction figure, as compared to the original figure, changes in size by the multiplier used with the original
  • area of an enlargement figure, as compared to the original figure, changes, but not by the multiplier used on the original figure; rather it grows by a greater factor than the multiplier
  • area of a reduced figure, as compared to the original figure, changes but not by the multiplier used on the original figure; rather it shrinks by a greater factor than the multiplier
For similar figures, what features (attributes) and measures stayed the same? What features (attributes) and measures changed? How does a multiplier play a role in these changes?

This Problem continues to focus on developing students’ informal understanding of the concept of similarity. It uses the context of copier size factors to introduce scale factors other than 2. Connecting back to the sixth-grade rational number Units, students explore scale factors of 75% and 150%. During the discussions in Problem 1.2 you may have already introduced the term corresponding to talk about corresponding sides and angles of shapes. If you haven’t discussed corresponding angles, corresponding sides, and/or how to name angles, use the introduction to Problem 1.3 prior to presenting the challenge.
Set up the photocopier context by talking with students about the rubber-band stretchers and other methods for enlarging figures.

• If you wanted to make a very accurate enlargement of a figure, would you use a rubber-band stretcher? (No)
  • What other ways do you know of to make a larger copy of something? (Students might mention a poster-making machine, a projector, and a photocopy machine. You will likely have many students who know that a photocopier can make enlargements and reductions but have never used one to do this. Be prepared to tell students that we enter a percent into the photocopier to tell it what size to make the copy.)

Project Learning Aid 1.3: Super Sleuth Figure and Two Copies to do a quick review of basic percent concepts. Cover up the captions under each figure. Tell students that the middle figure is the original.Suggested Questions

• Estimate the percent Daphne entered into the photocopier in order to get the smaller image on the left. Write your estimate in your notebook. (Student estimates can vary widely. Most will recognize that the smaller image is more than half of the original and so will guess something between 50% and 100%. This is as much precision as you ought to expect at this stage. Repeat the estimation with the enlarged figure. Make sure that students realize that the result of entering 100% into the photocopier would be an image identical to the original.)

Pay attention to how well your students are measuring. This is the first Problem in this Unit where more precision really makes sense, yet the comparisons are still relatively simple. Use this time to have students practice this important skill. Depending on how comfortable your students are with measuring, they may use rulers or transparent grid paper to measure side lengths; they may use angle rulers or protractors to measure angles.
If needed, this is also an opportunity to review operations with percents.

• What is the measurement of the base of the triangle in the smaller figure? (If the original figure’s base is 1.5 in., the smaller figure’s base ought to be 75% of this ( 1 1/8in.). Most students will get this first by measuring. Encourage some of this computation as well for review and practice.)
  • How could you use a rubber band stretcher to achieve 150% increase? (Answers will vary.)

Look for strategies that students use to compare features such as length and area. Some students will see immediately that the percents given are the right comparison. Some students will feel more comfortable comparing with fractions (the lengths on the smaller figure are about 3/4 of the original; some students might write ratios, saying that Copy 1 = 4 to 3 or 1 to 3/4 or 100% to 75%. (Portrayal)
What evidence will you use in the Summary to clarify and deepen understanding of the Now What Do You Know? What will you do if you do not have evidence?
For similar figures, what features (attributes) and measures stay the same? What features (attributes) and measures change? How does a multiplier play a role in these changes?

How are students answering the questions in the What If part? How are they describing the changes in the side lengths, area, and perimeter? Listen for their use of “for every” statements that you can expand on in the Summary. (Language)
Discuss the questions. Ask students to explain their reasoning. This will give you insight into their understanding of percent. Be sure to discuss angle measures, side lengths, and area.

Students may use addition strategies rather than multiplying by a scale factor. For example, they may divide the side lengths of the original figure by four equal segments and then subtract one of the segments to get the side length of the figure that has been reduced to 75%.
To get the side length of the figure that is increased to 150% students may divide the side lengths of the original figure into two equal segments and then add one of the segments to the original.
• How could you use a rubber band stretcher to achieve 150% increase? (Answers will vary.)

• How did you describe the comparison between the corresponding side lengths? (Answers will vary. Students will often use additive descriptions first such as, ”For 150% you just take the original and added on half as much.” Guide them to refine their thinking and use multiplicative structures to see that the side lengths are 1.5 times longer.)
  • To help students think about these ideas with a multiplicative structure versus additive you could ask them if there is a way to use a “for every” statement to express their idea. (“For every length on the original the corresponding length on the image is 1.5 times as long”.)
  • If I want to enlarge a figure by 25% will the image be larger or smaller than the original? What number do I enter in the photocopier? (To increase a figure by 25% you multiply the figure by a factor of 1.25. So, you enter 125% into the photocopier.) Explain why this is true.

This is a good time to review the Distributive Property. For example, to increase a figure by 25% means you multiply the original number by 25% and then add it to the original number. This is the same as multiplying the original number by 125% because x + 0.25x = 1x + 0.25x = (1 + 0.25)x = 1.25x.

Draw a square on a transparent grid on the overhead to show what happens with an increase of 25% To make the enlargement, first enlarge two adjacent sides of the original square, and then complete the square. Compare the two squares. (If the original side length is 1, then the new side length is 1.25. So, the lengths grew by a factor of 1.25. That is, each side length was multiplied by 1.25.)
Repeat this demonstration on a unit square with a decrease of 25%. In this case the scale factor is 0.75

• How is the photocopy similar to the rubber band method of creating similar figures? (Students will likely say that they are alike in that they each produce similar figures, but that they have only used rubber bands to enlarge figures.)

Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know questions. Push students towards describing the changes in the side lengths using multiplication versus additive descriptions.
Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.
• What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know?

1. Where did my students get stuck?
  2. What strategies did they use?
  3. What breakthroughs did my students have today?

• How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?
  • Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this Unit? The next Unit?

investigations.description: Investigation 2 The Mug Wump Family: Similar Figures
investigations.title: SAS Investigation 2 The Mug Wump Family: Similar Figures

text: In this Problem students learn how to make similar and non-similar shapes using a coordinate system. Students graph members of the Wump family, plus other figures that claim to be in the Wump family. Students will notice that members of the Wump family are similar to one another (Zug and Bug are both similar to Mug). The imposters (Glug and Lug) are not similar—one is distorted vertically and one is distorted horizontally. Corresponding angles are not congruent, and corresponding side lengths are not multiplied by the same factor. Students compare the shapes, side lengths, and angles of the figures they draw as they contrast similar figures with non-similar ones.
CCSSM: Responses to the reflection are informed by the work in the Investigation and thus also reflect 7.G.A.1, 7.RP.A.2, 7.RP.A.2.B
Early exploration of proportional relationships between corresponding side length, perimeter, and area of similar figures.
When exploring a set of geometric figures including an original and enlargement or a reduction, begin to use and articulate relationships between attributes, such as:

• corresponding angles of an enlargement or reduction of an original figure stay the same
  • side lengths of an enlargement or reduction figure, as compared to the original figure, change in size by the multiplier used with the original
  • perimeter of an enlargement or reduction figure, as compared to the original figure, change in size by the multiplier used with the original
  • area of an enlargement figure, as compared to the original figure, changes but not by the multiplier used on the original figure; rather it grows by a greater factor than the multiplier
  • area of a reduced figure, as compared to the original figure, changes but not by the multiplier used on the original figure; rather it shrinks by a factor greater than the multiplier.

How can you determine if an original figure and its image are similar by looking at the coordinate rule that produced the image? What features (attributes) stay the same for Mug and similar figures? What features change?

Students continue their exploration of scaled drawings/similarity by investigating transformations on the coordinate plane. In Problems 1.1 and 1.2, students created similar/scaled figures by using rubber bands and considered the result of an enlarged or reduced photocopy. Students continue to develop their ideas of how to transform figures that retain the same shape. In this Problem, students will create similar and non-similar figures using a coordinate system. (Portrayal)

If your students need to review graphing, you might introduce them to tic-tac-toe on a 4 × 4 board (explained below). The winner is the person who gets four in a row first (horizontally, vertically, or diagonally). The players take turns telling you two numbers that designate the location of the intersection point for their X or their O. This is different from the traditional game where the X’s and O’s are placed in the middle of each square. With little instruction, nearly every student will recall how to graph points in a hurry. This is a variation of the Four in a Row game that was introduced in the Shapes and Designs Unit.
Display Teaching Aid 2.1A: 4-by-4 Board or draw five horizontal and five vertical lines, equally spaced

If you choose not to do this activity and students have not done graphing in a while, it is well worth a brief mention that coordinates correspond to intersections of lines, not squares (regions). Many students believe that the location corresponds to the space instead of the intersection.

• How many of you know how to play tic-tac-toe?
  • How many do you need in a row to win? (three)
Today we will play a different version of tic-tac-toe. You will need four in a row to win.
We’ll play the left side of the class against the right side of the class. The left side can go first and tell me two numbers.

Have the first player tell you two numbers. If the numbers are between 0 and 4, they will be on the board. Otherwise, they will be off the board. For example, if a student says (5, 1), start at zero and count until you get to four and say, “Oops, they fell off the board!” Then let the other team have a turn. The students quickly learn to use the correct numbers and they quickly recognize that the order of the two numbers is important.
In future games, you can change the number scheme by moving the origin to a different place in the grid and by using negatives, fractions, etc.

After the students know their way around a coordinate grid, introduce the story of the video game whose star characters are the Wump family. You can show the Launch Video here to pique students’ interest in applications of the coordinate grid. Students may need help in drawing Mug Wump because the points are to be used in sets that are connected in order. You could do part of Mug as a whole class to make sure they know how to locate and connect the four sets of points. In addition, the students will need help in interpreting the symbolic rules for the points.

• The points for Zug are found from the points for Mug. The rule is (2x, 2y). What do you think this rule tells us to do to a Mug point to get a Zug point? (Multiply each coordinate by 2 or double the numbers for the coordinates.)
  • What do the other rules tell you to do for Lug, Bug, and Glug? (For Lug we multiply Mug’s x-coordinate by 3 and keep Mug’s y-coordinate the same. For Bug we multiply each coordinate by 3. For Glug we keep x the same and multiply the y-coordinate by 3.)
  • Go through your table and compute the new value of the x and y for each point. Remember that you are always starting with Mug’s x- and y-coordinates. Then locate the points and connect them in sets as you did for Mug.

When you feel your students are ready, launch the challenge of drawing all of the figures according to the rules given and comparing the final figures to see which ones look like they belong to the Wump family and which ones do not. Have students divide up the work in their groups of 3 or 4. Be sure that each student draws Mug and at least two other characters. They can share their work as a group so that collectively the group has all five figures. Learning Aid 2.1A: Coordinates of Game Characters and Learning Aid 2.1B 1-3: Grids will be helpful for students to keep track of their work. First-Quadrant Grid Learning Aid is an enlarged version of the coordinate grid, which may be useful for students who need larger print. (Agency, Identity, Ownership)

As students are working, their figures should look roughly like Mug Wump. One thing to ask students is if their new characters generally look like Mug as a quick check to see if they are plotting the points correctly. Be careful to avoid using the word similar as this has a particular mathematical meaning, especially in this Problem.

If students’ graphs are not resembling Mug, likely mistakes include not going in the correct order of the points, not calculating the coordinates correctly, reversing the order of the (x, y) coordinates (e.g., graphing (2, 1) as (1, 2)), and not starting over when the table indicates to do so. (Portrayal)
Help students plot and connect the points.
Part 2 is the mouth. Part 3 is the nose. Part 4 is the eyes.
Students may need help starting over to get the mouth, nose, and eyes.

• To create the coordinates for Zug, what must you multiply the coordinates of Mug by? (2)
  • Describe the shape of Mug. (Trapezoidal body, with rectangle legs and mouth, a triangle nose and two dots for eyes.)
  • What measures help you identify the imposters? (side lengths, angle measures, area, perimeter)
  • What features are the same about Mug and the others? (dots for eyes, rectangle mouth) What features are different? (size)
  • Which characters are Wump family members? (Mug, Zug, Bug)
  • What do you notice about the side lengths of a figure as compared to the corresponding side length of Mug? (Answers will vary. Zug and Bug will have a scale factor where Glug and Lug will not.)
  • What do you notice about the angle measures of a figure as compared to the corresponding angle measure of Mug? (They are the same for Mug, Zug, and Bug)
What evidence will you use in the summary to clarify and deepen understanding of the Now What Do You Know Question? What will you do if you do not have evidence?

How can you determine if an original and its image are similar by looking at the coordinate rule that produced the image? What features stay the same for Mug and similar figures? What features change?

Listen for the way students are deciding on the imposters. Take notes on groups that are using ratios, “for every” statements, etc. to describe the figures that are scaled drawings of Mug and use those in your Summary.

It is very helpful to display copies of the figures for the class to view. You can use Learning Aid 2.1B: Grids, Teaching Aid 2.1B: Wump Characters, and Teaching Aid 2.1C: Wump Characters on Grids. In one set the figures are on a coordinate grid, and in the other set the figures are on a blank page. You can cut the figures out and move them around to show the comparisons that the students are describing.

• How would you describe to a friend the growth of the figures that you drew? (They all increased in size. Some grew taller and wider, while one just grew taller, and one just grew wider.)
  • Which figures seem to belong to the Wump family and which do not? (Mug, Zug, and Bug have the same shape, but Lug and Glug are distorted.)
  • Are Lug and Glug related? Did they grow into the same shape? (No. Lug is wide and short while Glug is narrow and tall.)
  • Do you have any What If questions?

• Which characters are imposters? How do you know? (Glug and Lug. Flesh out how you know they are imposters by looking at side lengths, perimeters, areas, and angles as described in the following questions.)
  • In earlier Units in CMP, we learned that both the angles and the lengths of edges help determine the shape of the figure. How do the corresponding angles of the five figures compare? (Display the figures and compare corresponding angles. This reinforces that when you measure angles, you measure the amount of turn between the edges and not the lengths of the edges. In Mug, Zug, and Bug, the corresponding angles are equal. In Mug and Lug (or Glug), the corresponding angles (except the right angles) are not equal.)
  • Are the lengths related? Are some of them related and others not? How do the lengths in similar Wumps compare? (Compare some of the lengths to show that in Mug, Bug, and Zug, the corresponding lengths grow the same way. They are multiplied by the same number. Students will begin to notice that if the coefficients of both the x- and y-coordinates of the rule are the same, the figure is similar to the original. If the coefficients are different, the figure will change more in one direction than the other and will be distorted. One special case that you should help students notice is the case where we multiply the x and y by 1 to get a new figure. In this case the figures are similar. Even more, they are congruent. You get a figure of exactly the same size and shape. This case will occur in Problem 2.2.)
  • Are the perimeters related? Are some of them related and others not? How do the perimeters in similar Wumps compare? (Compare some of the perimeters – for example, the mouth or legs or one other part – to show that with Mug, Bug, and Zug, the corresponding perimeters grow the same way. They are multiplied by the same number. Students will begin to notice that if the coefficients of both the x- and y-coordinates of the rule are the same, the figure is similar to the original. If the coefficients are different, the figure will change more in one direction than the other and will be distorted. One special case that you should help students notice is the case where we multiply the x and y by 1 to get a new figure. In this case the figures are similar. Even more, they are congruent. You get a figure of exactly the same size and shape. This case will occur in Problem 2.2.)
  • Could you use ratios or “for every” statements to describe the characters that are similar to Mug? (Yes. For example, Bug is Similar to Mug. For every side length on Mug the corresponding side length on Bug is three times as long. The ratio to represent a side length on Mug and its corresponding side length on Bug is 1:3.)
  • For What If Situation A, which claims are correct? Why? (Marta, Jacob, and Billie are correct. Students should be able to talk about how the numbers in front of x and y (coefficients) must be the same so that all the side lengths increase by the same multiplier. Students should also recognize that the angles stayed the same in the Wump family members.)
  • What are some rules you could use to create a figure similar to Lug in What If Situation B? (Answers will vary but the rule should have x and y multiplied by the same number. Students may not have mastered using the rules at this point. They will have time to develop this further in the rest of this Investigation.)

If you have a document camera in your classroom, you can use it to compare Mug and Bug. Try to project Mug onto a picture of Bug by taping Bug to the screen or a blank wall. Then place Mug on the document camera and project Mug onto the figure of Bug. Move the projector closer or farther away to see if you can get the two to fit. The image of Mug should fit exactly onto Bug. Do the same for Mug and Glug. The image of Mug will not fit exactly onto Glug. Note: Try this on your own before doing it with the class.

For students who are ready for an extra challenge you could have them use the Mugwump Activity on Realize and create a rule that would have Mug appear in a different quadrant. (Agency, Identity, Ownership)

• How many ways can you do this?
  • How are the new Mug Wumps the same?
  • How are the new Mug Wumps different?

Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know questions. Assist students in making a connection between the coefficient of coordinate rules that produced scaled drawings and how the side lengths and perimeter change.
Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.
• What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know?

1. Where did my students get stuck?
  2. What strategies did they use?
  3. What breakthroughs did my students have today?

• How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?
  • Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this Unit? The next Unit?

problems.title: SAS 2.2 Hats Off to the Wumps
problems.subtitle: Changing a Figure's Size and Location

text: In this Problem, students investigate the effects that various algebraic rules have on the shape and location of a figure on a coordinate grid. The figure is a hat for Mug. Students explore what happens to the location of the hat when numbers are added to or subtracted from each coordinate. The figures are similar but may have changed location. In addition, they will be able to distinguish rules that produce similar figures from rules that do not produce similar figures, recognizing the role that multiplication plays in scaled drawings or similarity relationships. This geometric setting will lay a foundation for students later work on proportional relationships in Comparing and Scaling and Moving Straight Ahead.

Continue to explore enlarging, shrinking, and moving geometric figures using coordinate grids and rules that produce both similar and non-similar figures, including multipliers that are rational numbers. Expand understanding of which attributes change and which stay the same:

• corresponding angles of two similar figures are the same measure while angles of non-similar figures may not be.
  • corresponding side lengths of the similar figure increases or decreases by the multiplier used to create a new rule.
  • adding or subtracting numbers to a rule results in a figure moving on a grid but not in changing the shape or size of the new figure.

If you know the coordinate rules to create an image, how can you tell if the two figures are similar? How can you use the rule to predict the side lengths of the image? How is the effect of a coordinate rule like the effect of a rubber band stretcher or a copy machine setting?

Tell the students that this Problem is related to drawing the Wump family and imposters. In this case they are looking at hats for the Wump family. The hat is made from a rectangle and a triangle and has 6 vertices. This makes the figure simple enough that the students can concentrate on what is happening as they manipulate the rule by adding to each coordinate and/or multiplying each coordinate by a number.

Hand out Learning Aid 2.2A: Table for Mug’s Hat and Learning Aid 2.2B: Four First-Quadrant Grids. Have students look at the table and the grids that are provided. They should have little trouble drawing the figures. However, it is important that the students start the Problem knowing that the main point of the Problem is to look back over their drawings and make sense of what adding or multiplying in the rule does to the image.
After they have the hat and rules to look at, challenge students to find a way to predict what will happen to the image only by analyzing the rule and not drawing the figure.

Implementation Note: Drawing the hats in the Initial Challenge can be time consuming. During the What If you could have students do one of the situations and then have groups share the findings during the summary conversation.
You might have students draw two or more hats on the same grid. If students use a different color for each hat, it will be easier to differentiate the images.

• What does the rule tell you that you need to do to the x coordinate? y coordinate? (Answers will vary. Possible answer: For (x + 2, y + 3) you would add 2 to the x coordinate and add 3 to the y coordinate.)
  • Does adding or subtracting a number to the x or y coordinate make a difference? (It moves the shape on the gird)
  • What rule would give the largest possible image on the grids provided? (Answers will vary. Possible answer: (3x - 3, 3y).)
  • Make up a rule that would place the image in another quadrant. (Answers will vary. Possible answer: (x - 10, y - 5).)
Challenge the students to make up rules to fit your constraints. Students have worked with all four quadrants of the coordinate system and should be able to figure out how to move the figure around.

What If Situation C asks students to write a rule that would put the hat in the right place on the grid to fit on each Wump’s head and to transform the hat to the right size and location for the imposters. This task will be a good chance for the teacher to see if students are making sense of what multiplication in a rule does that is different from adding or subtracting.
Using Technology: Your students can use Coordinate Grapher, Desmos App, or another graphing technology to plot points on an electronic coordinate grid. (Agency, Identity, Ownership)
What evidence will you use in the Summary to clarify and deepen understanding of the Now What Do You Know? What will you do if you do not have evidence?

If you know the coordinate rules to create an image, how can you tell if the two figures are similar? How can you predict the side lengths of the image? How is the effect of a coordinate rule like the effect of a rubber band stretcher or a copy machine setting?

Look for how students are connecting the rules to the hats they are creating. Look for students who can explain the effect of fractional coefficients and adding/subtracting to the x or y coordinate. Select students/groups to explain how to move figures, enlarge or shrink figures on a grid using rules
Ask students what happened with each of the rules.

• Are the images similar to the original? Why or why not? (For (x + 2, y + 2) and (0.5x, 0.5y ), the images are all similar to the original. For (x + 2, 3y) and (2x, 3y), the images do not keep the same shape.)
Use student work or Teaching Aid 2.2: Wump Hats on Grids for students to prove their conjectures.

Note: The corner of the hat isn’t at the origin. Some students may think a hat has enlarged versus shifting locations. You may need to have a conversation surrounding this. You could tie it back to the other Problems. Everything they’ve done has had a fixed origin – the fixed point held down by their finger when using super stretchers; the corner of the page when using a copier and the origin of the grid when using coordinate graphs. Having a conversation about how all these methods are similar and/different can help clear this up as needed.

• How did adding to the coordinates change the hat? (Moved the hat to the right on the x axis and up on the y axis.)
  • How did subtracting to the coordinates change the hat? (Moved the hat to the left on the x axis and down on the y axis.)
  • Do adding and subtracting change a figure in the same way that multiplication changed Mug in Problem 2.1? (No. Multiplication changed the size while adding and subtracting change the location.)
  • What rule made a hat get smaller? Why? ((0.5 x, 0.5y) is the rule that made the hat get smaller. It multiplied the side lengths by ½ . When multiplying by a fraction you are finding a part of something so it would make the length of the new hat smaller.)
The hats of the set of figures are all made from a triangle and rectangle, but they are not all similar.

• How can you tell if two rectangles (or triangles) are similar? What information should you collect? (Students should say something about the measures of corresponding angles—that they are equal, congruent, or the same size. They should also say something about the lengths of corresponding sides. They may suggest gathering information on perimeter and area of the hats.)

Note: This last response is not an exact answer, but it is what students will be able to say from their experiences so far. Students will return to this question later and see that it is the coefficient, without regard to its sign, that makes the difference. If you multiply the x by - 2 and the y by 2, you still get a similar figure. (Time)

• What rule would make a hat with line segments the length of Hat 1’s line segments? (1/3x+2, 1/3y+3 )
  • What happens to a figure on a coordinate grid when you add to or subtract from its coordinates? (It relocates the figure on the grid.)
  • What rule would make a hat the same size as Hat 1 but moved up 2 units on the grid? (x + 2, y + 5)
  • What rule would make a hat with line segments twice as long as Hat 1’s line segments and then move it 8 units to the right? (2x + 10, 2y + 3)
  • Describe a rule that moves Hat 1 and does not produce a similar figure. (Answers will vary. Possible answer: (x + 4, 3y + 3))
  • What are the effects of multiplying each coordinate by a number? (If the numbers are the same, then the figures are similar. If the numbers are different, then the figures are not similar.)
  • What effect does the rule (5x - 5, 5y + 5) have on the original hat? (The figure would be similar. Its sides will be 5 times as large, and then the stretched image will be moved to the left 5 units and up 5 units.)
  • What about the rule ( 1/4x, 4y - 5/6)? (This rule would not give a similar figure. The figure is shrunk horizontally and stretched vertically. The image is also moved down 5/6 of a unit.)
  • Make up a rule that will shrink the figure, keep it similar, and then move it to the right and up. (Answers will vary. Possible answer: (2/3 x + 3, 2/3 y + 1) will make the shape 2/3 the lengths, move it 3 units to the right, and 1 unit up.)
  • Hat 5 is not similar to Mug’s Hat. Write a rule that transforms Hat 5 to a figure that is similar to Mug’s Hat. (Answers will vary. Possible answers: Multiply 2x by 1/2 and 3y by 1/3 . This results in Mug’s Hat. Or multiply 2x by 3 (resulting in 6x), and multiply 3y by 2 (resulting in 6y).)
  • Describe how to transform Hats 1–5 back to Mug’s Hat. (Students may do this either symbolically or in words. For example, for Hat 2 they might suggest adding 1 to the x-values and subtracting 4 from the y-values. For Hat 4, multiplying each coordinate by 2 results in Mug’s Hat. This question pushes students to think about undoing the process of transformation (or finding the inverse transformation); the result should be the original (x, y) pair for Mug’s Hat.)
  • Without drawing, predict the size and location of a hat made from the rule (0.5x - 1, 0.5y + 4). Is it similar to Mug’s Hat? Explain. (It is similar to Mug’s Hat. The image will shrink by the same factor, 0.5, both horizontally and vertically. The side lengths will all be half as long as the side lengths of Mug’s Hat. Then the image will be moved left 1 unit and up 4 units.)

Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know questions. Take note of how students are talking about using addition and subtraction differently than multiplication. This is another step for students in understanding the differences in the additive and multiplicative structures of number.
Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.
• What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know?

1. Where did my students get stuck?
  2. What strategies did they use?
  3. What breakthroughs did my students have today?

• How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?
  • Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this Unit? The next Unit?

problems.title: SAS 2.3 Mouthing Off and Nosing Around
problems.subtitle: Scale Factors

text: Students continue to work with the Wump family as they investigate side lengths, angles, perimeters, and areas of similar rectangles and triangles. Students use the idea of same shape to discover that scaled drawings/similar figures have corresponding angles that have the same measure and that corresponding sides grow or shrink by the same factor. Proportional reasoning is the ability to make comparisons between objects using multiplicative thinking instead of additive thinking.

The vocabulary of scale factor is introduced. As students analyze the diagram of noses and mouths from the Wump family, they will notice that scale factor only applies to these scaled drawings or similar figures. Scale factor does not apply to non-similar figures, as pairs of corresponding sides do not grow or shrink by the same factor. This problem will help solidify for students how using a scale factor is applying their proportional reasoning.
Introduce the terms “scale factor” and connect it to “multiplier” to describe the relationship between corresponding side lengths of similar figures.
Use knowledge of scale drawings/similar figures to determine if any two rectangles or two triangles are similar.
Identify the scale factor of any two similar figures
Represent the relationship between corresponding sides of similar figures with a ratio.
How can you decide if two shapes are similar? How can you determine the scale factor between two similar shapes?

Discuss the pair of similar rectangles in the introduction to Problem 2.3. Ask students to describe the relationship between the side lengths when going from the large shape to the smaller shape and vice versa. You can show the Launch Video here to reinforce the relationships between corresponding angles and corresponding sides of similar figures.(Language)
This Launch Video gives students a dynamic representation of similar figures.

A man is building houses for his cat and dog, and he wants their houses to be similar to his own. As he puts the roofs on the houses, he discusses their characteristics. The pairs of corresponding sides of the triangular roofs are highlighted in succession, as are the pairs of corresponding angles.
Tell the class that the challenge is to use the criteria of corresponding angles and side lengths to determine which rectangles (mouths) and which triangles (noses) are similar.
The following statements are true for similar figures.

• Corresponding angles have the same measure.
  • Corresponding side lengths from one figure to the other are multiplied by the same scale factor.

Because corresponding sides and angles constitute an essential idea, you may want to be explicit with students about the need for labeling figures. The vertices of the Wump mouths and noses are not labeled. You could label these vertices to clear up any difficulties in referring to specific sides later. (Language and Time)
As the students work in pairs, look for students who are having trouble sorting out corresponding sides when finding side lengths.

Urge the students to organize their work. They can record their measurements on the figures. If they use a chart, they will need some way to distinguish the sides (such as “vertical” and “horizontal” or “base” and “height”). (Language)
To compare areas, some students may find the area of each rectangle and triangle by using formulas for areas. Others may count the squares that cover each figure.

If some students finish early, encourage them to draw two more rectangles—one that is similar to the Wump family’s mouth and one that is not similar. Repeat for triangles. Be sure to use these figures in the Summarize. There are additional Going Further suggestions in the Summarize. (Time)

• Have you considered the corresponding angles? (They must be congruent to be similar)
  • How might you compare corresponding side lengths? (Look for a scale factor)
  • How can you find the scale factor if you used a rubber band stretcher? Coordinate graphs? (Scale factor is the number of rubber bands used or the coefficient of the x and y coordinate.)
What evidence will you use in the Summary to clarify and deepen understanding of the Now What Do You Know? What will you do if you do not have evidence?
How can you decide if two shapes are similar? How can you determine the scale factor between two similar shapes?

During the Initial Challenge take note of the strategies that students are using to find the scale factor. How are students providing evidence for the similar figures in the Initial Challenge? Do they measure all angles and sides? Are some students informally seeing that angle alone for triangles can determine similarity? For the rectangles are they ignoring the right angles and only looking at the side lengths. During the What If look for how students describe the ideas using proportional reasoning to find a scale factor.

Discuss the answers. Ask for explanations. For rectangles J and L, students may talk about the width growing by 2 and the length growing by 2. The perimeters also grow by a factor of 2. This gives you an opportunity to help students describe the growth in a different way. We say that the widths, lengths, and perimeters grow by a scale factor of 2. Note that Rectangle L is Mug’s mouth and Triangle O is Mug’s nose.

• How can you decide if two figures are similar? (They are similar when their corresponding angles have the same measure and their corresponding sides grow by the same scale factor.)
  • Do you agree with Zack that you can use ratios (proportional reasoning) to show that the scale factor is the same for corresponding side lengths? Why or Why not? (Yes, proportional reasoning is the ability to make comparisons between objects using multiplicative thinking instead of additive thinking and when you are using a scale factor all the side lengths are multiplied or “grow” by that amount.)
  • I want to grow a new Wump from Wump 1 (Mug). The scale factor is 9. What are the dimensions and perimeter of the new Wump’s mouth? (36 × 9, p = 90)
  • If the scale factor is 75, what are the measurements of the new mouth? (300 by 75)
  • Why are the dimensions 300 by 75? What rule would produce this figure? (The scale factor tells what to multiply the old sides by to get the new sides. Since Mug’s mouth is 4 by 1, the new mouth is 4 × 75 by 1 × 75 or 300 by 75. The rule is (75x, 75y).)
Note: These questions connect back to Variables and Patterns in 6th grade. Students are looking for an algebraic rule to relate Mug’s mouth to other Wump family mouths.

• Why does the perimeter grow the same way as the lengths of the sides of a rectangle? (Students should be able to explain that the perimeter is really a length, so it behaves like the width and length. Some might say that the perimeter = 2(ℓ+ w), and if the scale factor is 2, then the new perimeter = 2(2ℓ + 2w) and this is just double the original perimeter. A few students might recognize that 2(2ℓ + 2w) = 2 × 2(ℓ + w) or that in the expression 2(2ℓ + 2w), the factor 2 ℓ + 2w is the perimeter of the original rectangle.)
  • Let’s go in the reverse direction. How can you find the scale factor from the original to the image if all you have are the dimensions of the two similar figures? (We need to divide the length of a side of the image by the length of the corresponding side of the original figure.)
  • For similar rectangles, the perimeter of the image is the scale factor times the perimeter of the original rectangle. Do you think this is true for similar triangles? (Yes. For example, if the scale factor is 3, each side of the triangle will grow by a factor of 3. When you add all three side lengths of the image, the sum of the lengths is the original perimeter times 3.)
You might try this on one of the triangles in the Problem. Students should be able to measure the sides of the triangle with enough accuracy to verify the reasoning.
Once you feel students have some ideas about similarity and scale factor, probe students’ understanding of similarity by asking the reverse of some of the above questions:

• If the perimeter of the mouth of a new Wump family member is 150, what are the length, width, and area of its mouth? What scale factor was used to grow this new Wump from Mug 1? (If the perimeter is 150, then I must find a number that when the original perimeter (10) is multiplied by this number, the product is 150, that is, 10 × . So, I divide 150 by 10 to get 15, which is the scale factor. Therefore, the length is 60, the width is 15, and the area is 900.)
  • What scale factor is needed to produce a new mouth (rectangle) whose perimeter is 5? (This requires students to shrink the original rectangle by a scale factor of .)
Repeat some of the questions above for triangles. It is best if you use the original nose (Triangle O) as the reference.

As part of the Summarize or as an extension, you could extend the idea of similar rectangles to similar quadrilaterals. On grid paper, draw a quadrilateral (or a parallelogram) that is not a rectangle. Make a similar quadrilateral using a scale factor of 2. (To do this, students need to keep corresponding angles congruent. Limiting it to nonrectangular parallelograms would be a bit easier.) Compare the corresponding lengths of the two figures. Compare the measures of the corresponding angles.

All the triangles and rectangles are in the correct orientation to make it easier to reason about similarity when comparing corresponding sides. Rotate Rectangle J (or draw a new rectangle that looks like J rotated) and ask students whether this rectangle is similar to Rectangle L. Some students may say it is not similar because comparing the bases and the heights results in different ratios. However, similarity of shapes does not change under a rotation (or a flip).
Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know questions.
Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.
• What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know?

1. Where did my students get stuck?
  2. What strategies did they use?
  3. What breakthroughs did my students have today?

• How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?
  • Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this Unit? The next Unit?

investigations.title: SAS Investigation 3 Scaling Perimeter and Area

problems.title: SAS 3.1 Using Proportional Reasoning to Rep-tile

text: This Problem challenges students to find ways of putting multiple copies of a figure together to make a larger, similar figure. This process is called rep‑tiling. Rep‑tiling allows students to revisit similarity in a new context. In deciding how to put rep‑tiles together, students identify relationships between the scale factor, side lengths, and areas of similar figures. For example, they find that if the scale factor from a smaller quadrilateral to a larger quadrilateral is 2, the side lengths and perimeter grow by a factor of 2. The area, however, grows by a factor of 22, or 4.

Implementation Note: Creating the rep-tiles takes time for students to cut, manipulate and draw. Due to this it may take 1.5 days to complete this task. Having a conversation after students have completed the Initial Challenge can help them focus their thinking between the two class periods.
How do rep-tiles show the relationship between the scale factor and the perimeter and area of similar shape?
Explore enlarging a geometric figure using “rep-tiling. Expand understanding of similar figures and which attributes change and which stay the same:

• corresponding angles of two similar figures are the same measure while angles of non-similar figures may not be.
  • corresponding side length of the rep-tile (similar figure) increases by the scale factor used to create a new figure.
  • perimeter of the rep-tile (similar) figure increases by the scale factor
  • area of the rep-tile (similar) figure increases by the scale factor squared.

In the previous Investigation, students explored the relationship between the corresponding sides, corresponding angles, perimeters, and areas of similar figures. This Problem continues students’ exploration of scale factors and similarity by rep-tiling, or building shapes from copies of smaller, similar shapes.

In each of these contexts, students study how the areas of two similar figures are related to the scale factor. It is often surprising to students that if they apply a scale factor of 2 to a figure (or in general, n), the area becomes four times as great (in general, n2 as great).

At this stage, students should not be concerned with area calculations. Instead, students use rep-tiles to see that when they apply a scale factor of 2, it requires four copies of the original figure. In this case, students measure area using the original figure as the unit rather than units of square inches or square centimeters.

This Launch video animates a section of the Introduction in the Student Edition. The animation shows two tessellations and asks students to think about the difference between the tessellations. From this, students can identify what patterns can be used to classify a tessellation as a rep-tile. Use this animation either as a supplement or a replacement of the first section of the Introduction in the Student Edition.

• How are these patterns similar? (The patterns both tessellate. The shapes fit together exactly with no overlap or underlap.)
  • What is different about these patterns that might make one a rep‑tile and the other not?

Note: A regular hexagon will tessellate because it fits together with no overlaps or underlaps. It has a pattern that can be continued forever. However, there is no larger regular hexagon in the pattern formed by the small hexagons. The regular hexagon tessellates, but it is not a rep‑tile. On the other hand, if you put four squares together, you can make a larger square that is similar to the small squares. Students will find other figures for which this is the case.

Students are going to work with quadrilaterals and triangles. The challenge is to determine which types of quadrilaterals and triangles are rep‑tiles. For each shape, find whether it is possible to put together several identical small shapes to form a larger version of the same shape. When it is possible, you will sketch how the shapes fit together and answer some questions about the measurements of the figures.
Students can work with partners or in small groups.

Students can use their own drawings, the Shapes Set, or copies of Learning Aid 3.1: Quadrilaterals for Rep-Tiles (accessibility) and Learning Aids 3.1B: Triangles for Rep-Tiles (Portrayal) to make copies of figures. If they fold a piece of paper in fourths, trace a figure, and then cut it out, students will have four congruent copies of that figure.

Students may want to use colored pencils so that they can clearly see the borders between figure copies. Rulers can be helpful as well. Students can use them as straight‑edges when sketching, and also measure lengths in order to find scale factors. Students can use angle

Implementation Note: Stopping after students have worked on the Initial Challenge to have a short conversation can help students to stay focused on the math. Students can get lost in the cutting, drawing, and/or manipulating shape sets and miss the mathematics. Have a brief conversation on which ones they were able to rep-tile and then send them to the What If.

Some students’ spatial skills enable them to find rep‑tiles more quickly than others. To scaffold for students who need some suggestions to move forward you can suggest students can systematically explore the possibilities. Point out that it is reasonable to assume that edges with the same length must be placed together. Keep in mind that there are usually two ways to place two matching edges together, as one of the shapes can be flipped.

Implementation Note: Some teachers have students make a poster with each rep‑tile the group finds. They display these posters as a handy reference for future discussions about the relationship between area and scale factor. (Time and Portrayal) Students can also use Learning Aid 3.1C Rep-tile Recording Sheet to keep track of their work.

As you circulate, make sure that the students have arranged the copies of the rectangles or triangles in such a way that the larger figure is similar to the smaller figure. Make sure that students have a way to compare the side lengths of the smaller figures to the side lengths of the larger figures.

You might ask students if they have checked angle measures. Some may use a transparent piece of paper to copy and compare. Others may use angle rulers or protractors. Students should notice that corresponding angles are congruent. They need to make sure that the angles they are comparing are corresponding.

• How do you know that your original triangle and your new, larger triangle are similar? (Possible answer: The two triangles have the same angle measures. Also, each set of corresponding side lengths has the same scale factor.)
  • How can you determine which angles or which side lengths correspond in the similar figures? (Possible answer: I can see the larger triangles is a rotated version of the smaller triangle. I find the longest side for the original triangle and the longest side for the new triangle. This helps me to determine how the triangle was rotated.
  • How many rectangles will it take to make a larger, similar figure formed by the rectangles? (4)
  • How many rectangles will it take to make the next larger, similar figure formed by the rectangles? (9)
  • We will call these similar figures rep‑tile figures. How many rectangles will it take to make the 10th rep‑tile figure? (Students may not yet understand the link between area and scale factor. At this point, students should see the relationship between areas of similar figures and small scale factors such as 2, 3, or 4. Some students may already know that 100 rectangles would form the 10th rep‑tile figure.)
The four parallelograms below form a larger parallelogram, but it is not similar to the original. You might ask students to decide for themselves whether or not this is true and explain why.
For students who need an extra challenge ask them if a trapezoid will rep-tile and to provide evidence of what they find.
What evidence will you use in the Summary to clarify and deepen understanding of the Now What Do You Know? What will you do if you do not have evidence?
How do rep-tiles show the relationship between the scale factor and the area of similar shape?
Listen to students as they are discussing the questions in the What If. Use their responses to frame your summary.

You can have different groups of students display their rep‑tiles during the Summarize. Students can use their copies of use Learning Aid 3.1C Rep-tile Recording Sheet or a large classroom poster during a gallery walk to draw some conclusions. Students should look at the displayed rep‑tiles and record any new information or questions that they have about rep‑tiles. Groups can share their observations, but be sure they provide explanations. Teaching Aid: Answers for Triangles or Teaching Aid: Answers for Quadrilaterals could be used as well.

Encourage the class to verify the explanations or to ask questions of each other. Ask questions that require students to focus on the relationship between the scale factor and areas of the similar figures. Students should be able to articulate that the area of the larger rep-tile figure is the square of the scale factor times the original area. They should have mental images of the rep-tiles to support that fact.
Have groups share what they found on the Situations they worked on from the What If section.
Be sure that the students understand the relationship between scale factor and perimeter, and between scale factor and area. This Problem will make visible students’ proportional reasoning skills.

• Do you have any What If questions?
  • How does the side of the smaller quadrilateral or triangle compare to the side of the larger figure? (Encourage students to describe the growth in terms of multiplying by a common factor, for example: the side of the larger figure is twice as long as the side of the smaller figure, or the smaller figure has a side that is half as long as the side of the larger figure.)
  • How do the angles of the original quadrilateral or triangle compare to the angles of the rep‑tile figure? (The angles have the same measure.)
  • How many original shapes are needed to cover the rep-tile? (Answers will vary depending on the scale factor.)
  • If the area of a triangle is 15 square units, and the scale factor between the triangle and a larger, similar triangle is 2.5, what is the area of the similar triangle? (93.75 square units)
  • If the area of a triangle is 15 square units, and the scale factor between the triangle and a smaller, similar triangle is 0.5, what is the area of a similar triangle? (3.75 square units)
The following discussion refers to rectangles. You can include parallelograms from the start, or you can repeat the discussion after you have finished discussing rectangles.
Take four copies of the smaller rectangle and make the first rep‑tile figure.

• How many smaller rectangles do I need to make the next larger rep‑tile figure? (5)
  • How many rectangles are there altogether? (9)
  • Predict what will happen for the next rep‑tile figure. (You will need 16 total rectangles to make the next rep‑tile figure.)
  • What pattern do you see when extending the rep‑tile figures? (You can find out how many of the original copies are needed to make the rep‑tile figure by using the scale factor. You need to square the scale factor to find the number of rectangles needed for the rep‑tile.)
  • Predict how many rectangles we’ll need for the 10th rep‑tile figure. (102 or 100 rectangles)
Sketch a triangle or quadrilateral for the class to use to answer these questions.

• Can you subdivide this triangle or quadrilateral into smaller congruent triangles or quadrilaterals? What is the scale factor? How do the perimeters and areas compare? (Answers may vary. If the scale factor is 1/2, then the perimeter of each smaller triangle or quadrilateral is 1/2 the perimeter of the larger triangle or quadrilateral. The area of each smaller triangle or quadrilateral is 1/4 the area of the larger one. For a scale factor of 1/3, the perimeter of the smaller triangle is 1/3 the perimeter of the larger triangle. The area is 1/9 the area of the larger triangle.)

Students may observe other patterns. They might start talking about the relationship of the ratios of the side lengths.
