This will get developed more in Investigation 4, but it may come out informally as students look at the rep-tile and the original shape. Students might suggest that the line that joins the midpoints of two sides of a triangle looks like it is parallel to the third side. You might ask them how they would prove this. This will facilitate a discussion on transversals and the angles formed by them.
The number pattern associated with the sequence of rep-tile areas is:
The following diagram is a geometric interpretation of the above sequence using squares:

Students may say that the pattern is found by adding consecutive odd integers, and the sum is the square of the number of integers being summed. For example, the sum of the first 5 odd integers is 52, or 25. The sum of the first 10 odd integers is 102, or 100. Some students may verbalize this to say that the sum of the first n odd integers is n2.

Have a conversation about What If Situation B. Students understanding of triangles, angles of a triangle, and ratios are all addressed in this question. It is a chance to gather information on what students are understanding about triangles and lay some groundwork for future work in Investigations 3 and 4.
Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know questions.

  2. What strategies did they use?

problems.title: SAS 3.2 Designing Under Constraints
problems.subtitle: Scale Factors and Similar Shapes (Scale Drawings)

text: In this Problem, students use scale factors or other information to make figures that are similar to a specific triangle or rectangle. They also find missing side lengths and angle measures in pairs of similar figures.

At this stage, students tend to first find the scale factor between a pair of similar figures, then multiply the scale factor by a given side length to obtain the measure of the missing, corresponding side length.

Students find missing angle measures by recalling that similar figures have corresponding angles with the same measure. They need to recall that the sum of the measures of the interior angles of a triangle is 180°, which they learned in Shapes and Designs. In the next Investigation, students will find missing side lengths by using ratios.

Continue to explore enlarging and shrinking rectangles and triangles and exploring how the scale factor impacts side lengths, perimeter, and area of new scale drawings but not the measures of the angles

• corresponding side lengths and perimeter of the similar figure increases or decreases by the scale factor (multiplier).
  • area of similar figures increases or decreases by the scale factor squared (multiplier squared)
Expand understanding of how attributes of two similar figures are affected by the scale factor

• use the understanding to find lengths of corresponding side lengths that have missing measures
  • use the understanding to find angle measures of corresponding angles that have missing measures.
How can you use scale factors to draw similar figures (scale drawings)? How can you use scale factors to find missing information about angles measures? Side lengths? Area? Perimeter?
In this Problem, students continue to build on their understanding of scale factors and scaled drawings or similarity.

• If you are given a rectangle, how might you draw a similar rectangle with a scale factor of 2? (Calculate twice the length for each side of the rectangle, and then draw a rectangle with those measurements.)
  • How would the areas of the original rectangle and the rectangle you drew relate? (The new rectangle would have an area 4 times as great as the original rectangle.)
  • What would the scale factor be for a pair of similar figures where one figure has an area 16 times as great as the other figure? (4)
  • What is base of a triangle? (This can be any side of a triangle.)
  • What is the height of a triangle? (Perpendicular distance from the base to the opposite vertex.)
Display Rectangle A and Triangle B for the class. Tell the class that their challenge is to draw similar figures with the conditions given in the Problem.
Implementation Note: Assign one or two from each set to partner groups. Have students create posters to present their findings.

• What are the side lengths of Rectangle A? (4 units and 8 units)
  • What is the area of Rectangle A? (32 square units)
  • What is the area of Triangle B? (14 square units)

Pass out Learning Aid 3.2A: Designing Under Constraints. Students may also want to use Quarter-inch Grid Paper, angle rulers or protractors and rulers. Give students time to begin this Problem independently before they work with a partner. (Agency, Identity, Ownership)

Check to make sure that students are identifying the correct scale factor in the parts that give information about area. For example, in the Initial Challenge and Triangle X, if the area of the sketched figure must be 16 times the area of the original figure, students must understand that the area grows by the square of the scale factor. So, in this case, the scale factor is 4.

• Can using corresponding sides help you? (yes)
  • Can using corresponding angle help you? (yes)
  • What is the scale factor from one shape to the other? (Answers will vary.)

To move conversations forward on corresponding parts for the similar rectangles, ask students which side has the shortest length. Then, ask which side has the longest length. This will help them match corresponding sides. (Language)
Look for students who solve the Problem in interesting ways. Be sure to call on these students to share their ideas during the Summarize.
What evidence will you use in the summary to clarify and deepen understanding of the Now What Do You Know? What will you do if you do not have evidence?
How can you use scale factors to draw similar figures (scale drawings)? How can you use scale factors to find missing information about angle measures? Area? Perimeter?
As students present their solutions, be sure they explain their reasoning and methods.

To find the missing lengths in the What If, students might find the scale factor by dividing two of the known, corresponding lengths of the similar figures. They can then multiply the scale factor by a known length to find the corresponding, unknown length. Be sure that students are using the correct scale factor. That is, they need to find the scale factor from the figure with the known length to the figure with the unknown length.

Implementation Note: As an optional enrichment activity, you can hand out copies of Learning Aid 3.2B: Polygon Sets for students to extend their understanding of similarity to other polygons. As a further extension, you can assign side lengths to the polygons on this Learning Aid and ask students to find missing side measures.
As the students work with Learning Aid 3.3B: Polygon Sets:

• In each set, which polygons are similar? Explain how you know. (Rectangles A and C are similar, Parallelograms B and C are similar, Decagons A and B are similar, and Stars A and C are similar. For the rectangles, we need to check only the side lengths. The corresponding side lengths from one figure to the other must grow by the same scale factor. For the others, we need to check the angle measurements as well. For a pair of similar figures, angle measures are congruent.)

Students should be solidifying the use of scale factor and how it effects length, perimeter and area of similar figures. Having conversations on how they created the similar rectangle or triangle for the constraints will make this understanding visible. This is an example of a conversation that took place in one classroom about creating Rectangle R:
Teacher: How did you draw Rectangle R?
Alvin: In our group we first drew a rectangle with side lengths that were ¼ the size of the side lengths on Rectangle A, but that was incorrect.
Janice: Are you sure it is incorrect? That is what we did and we think it is correct.

Alvin: It is incorrect because the scale factor of ¼ made the sides get ¼ the size but the area became (1)/16 the size. The area of Rectangle A is 32 square units because it is an 8 by 4 rectangle. When we incorrectly used a scale factor of ¼, we got a rectangle with dimensions of 2 by 1. This gave Rectangle 2 an area of 2. The direction that our new rectangle should have an area of ¼ of Rectangle A or 8 square units. Our rectangle is 2 square units or 1/16 the area of Rectangle A.
Janice: Ok. I see. So, if the scale factor is ¼ then the area of the new rectangle will be 1/16 of original area. How do we get a rectangle that is ¼ the area of the original?
Teacher: What did we find from Problem 3.1 about the relationship between scale factor and area?
Shannon: That the scale factor times itself will give you the change in the area.
Teacher: We need a change in area of ¼ the size.
Antoine: So, we are looking for a number of times itself that will be ¼.
Alvin: Right, so the scale factor must be ½ because ½ x ½ = ¼. That means the new rectangle would be a 4 by 2. This has an area of 8 square units which is ¼ the original area of 32 square units.

Shannon: We got the same rectangle but did it differently. We knew that Rectangle A had an area of 32 square units and the new rectangle had to be ¼ of that or 8 square units. We tried a 1 by 8 rectangle but a scale factor didn’t exist between that one and Rectangle A. Then we tried a 4 by 2 rectangle and that worked with a scale factor of ½.

By the end of this Investigation, students should have a firm understanding of the two criteria for identifying similar figures – 1) consistent scale factors for corresponding sides and congruent corresponding angles and 2) the relationship between scale factor and comparisons of lengths, perimeters, and areas of two similar figures. (Time)
• If this rectangle is enlarged by a scale factor of 3, what is the perimeter of the enlargement? What is the area of the enlargement? (perimeter: 63 units; area: 202.5 square units)

Discuss how the students found the missing side lengths and angle measures for the two situations in the What If. (Students should be able to use the scale factor to find the measures of the corresponding side lengths and use their understanding that corresponding angles will have the same measurement.)
Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know questions.
Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.
• What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know?

1. Where did my students get stuck?
  2. What strategies did they use?
  3. What breakthroughs did my students have today?

• How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?
  • Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this Unit? The next Unit?

In this Problem, students use similar triangles to measure distances on the ground that cannot be measured directly. The Student Edition provides a diagram to illustrate this idea. However, if possible, you can reenact the Problem in a real‑life setting.

Students revisit what it means for triangles to be similar. They recall that they can use similar triangles, and the scale factor between the triangles, to find unknown corresponding lengths. They apply these ideas in finding an inaccessible distance across a river.
Introduce the term “nested triangles” and broaden understanding of similar triangles.
Use knowledge of similar figures/scale drawings and apply it to nested triangles to solve real world distance problems that are difficult to physically measure.
How can you use similar triangles to find a distance that is difficult to measure?

This animation provides students with the context of Problem 3.3. Show your students this animation before reading through the Student Edition Introduction. Students will see that math can help them to solve real-world problems, such as how to measure the distance across a wide river.

Describe the Problem to the class. Ask how it is similar to Problem 3.2. Have the class identify the similar triangles and find the corresponding angles and sides. You may want to introduce the term nested in the Launch for this Problem to describe the two triangles pictured in Problem 3.3 in the Student Edition. It is a handy, though nontechnical, way to describe a smaller triangle within a larger triangle, where the triangles share an angle. (Language)

In the two previous Problems, we used the fact that if two triangles have congruent corresponding angles, then the triangles are similar. This is not generally true for other polygons. Explain why this is not true for parallelograms or rectangles. ( All rectangles have four 90° angles, yet not all rectangles are similar. Corresponding side lengths in two rectangles can have different scale factors. Likewise, for any parallelogram, we can stretch just one pair of sides, as in the diagram below. The parallelogram maintains the same angles but results in a figure that is not similar to the original.)

• What shapes do you see on the diagram?
  • What measurements do you need?

Note: In general, it is true that if the corresponding angles of two triangles are congruent, then the triangles are similar. In this Unit, we assume that this theorem is true. A proof for the theorem is developed in 8th grade.
Have the students use the diagram to find the distance across the river. Make sure they provide explanations for their methods.
Be sure the groups have identified the similar triangles and the corresponding sides and angles they need to measure. (Portrayal)

• How many triangles do you see in the river diagram? (Students may point out that they see two triangles and a trapezoid, or just one triangle and a trapezoid. It is important that students focus on the two triangles. The corresponding side lengths will link the sides of the small triangle to sides of the large triangle, not the trapezoid.)
  • Are the triangles in the river diagram similar? How do you know? (The triangle formed by Stakes 1, 2, and 3 is similar to the triangle formed by Stake 3 and Trees 1 and 2. These triangles have angles that are congruent. The angle at Tree 1 is 90° and corresponds to the angle at Stake 1 which is also 90°. The triangles share the angle formed at Stake 3. The angle formed at Tree 2 has the same measure as the angle formed at Stake 2. This is because the line segment from Tree 1 to Tree 2 is parallel to the line segment from Stake 1 to Stake 2 and the angle at Stake 2 corresponds to the angle at Tree 2. The important features of this figure are that Tree 1, Stake 1 and Stake 3 are on the same line; Tree 2, Stake 2, and Stake 3 are on the same line; and the segments connecting Stakes 1 and 2 and Trees 1 and 2 are parallel. These conditions allow students to use their knowledge of transversals.)
Learning Aid 3.3: River Diagrams shows both the diagram and the modified diagram described in the What If Situation B.

Since the distance across the river is a portion of a side length of the larger triangle, some students may have difficulty isolating just the distance across the river. Be sure that students can use details to explain their processes.

• Can you sketch the two similar triangles? (Answers will vary)
  • What do you know about the angles of the two triangles? (The corresponding angles are equivalent.)
  • Which sides correspond on the two triangles? (Answers will vary)
  • What is the scale factor between the smaller triangle and the larger triangle in the Initial Challenge? (1.75)
What evidence will you use in the Summary to clarify and deepen understanding of the Now What Do You Know? What will you do if you do not have evidence?
How can you use similar triangles to find a distance that is difficult to measure directly?
Look for students using scale factor to find missing sides lengths.

When all groups have made their calculations, give each group a chance to share their work. If there are a variety of answers, ask the class why groups arrived at different answers. See if students can explain to others how to correct their work. This is a good opportunity to discuss accuracy with the class.

• Describe the relationship between the perimeter of the smaller triangle and the perimeter of the larger rectangle in the Initial Challenge? (The larger triangle has a perimeter that is 1.75 times as large.) In the What If Situation B? (The larger triangle has a perimeter that is 4 times as large.)
  • Discuss What If Situation A and students’ thinking around Durrell’s suggestion. (Portrayal) (Answers will vary. This connects back to ideas of unit rate. The rep-tile would have to have measures that keep the 80:120 ratio, and end up fitting into 140 feet, so Durrell could use a triangle with sides 2’ : 3’ (or 1:1.5) and rep-tile that up to 140: 210)
  • In What If Situation B, what order do you think these students located the key points and measure the segments and angles? Explain your reasoning. (Answers will vary.)
Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know question(s).

1. Where did my students get stuck?
  2. What strategies did they use?
  3. What breakthroughs did my students have today?

investigations.title: SAS Investigation 4 Similar Figures and Ratios

problems.title: SAS 4.1 Equivalent Ratios within Similar Figures

text: In Problem 4.1, students find a ratio for adjacent side lengths within a figure. They compare this ratio to the ratio for adjacent sides in corresponding positions within another figure. They recognize that, for similar figures, these ratios are equivalent. Students also find the scale factor between similar figures. They then compare the information that is given by the scale factor to the information that is given by the ratios of adjacent side lengths. Students notice that they can use angle measures and side-length ratios to test for similarity in triangles.

Note: In Grade 6, ratios were expressed as comparison statements such as “For every $3 Mary raises, Liz raises $5.” The ratio of the amount of money Mary raises to the amount Liz raises is 3 : 5. In this Investigation, ratios are also written as fractions such as 3/5 or 5/3. This Unit, and in particular this Investigation, leads naturally to the next Unit, Comparing and Scaling. In Comparing and Scaling, students will continue to explore ratio and proportion, and develop strategies to solve problems that involve proportions.
Introduce the idea that ratios can be represented as fractions, extending their use from just comparison statements.

Explore the relationship between ratios of corresponding adjacent side lengths within two similar figures. Build off understanding of scale factor between similar figures to begin to understand why these ratios are equal.
What information do the ratios of adjacent side lengths within two similar figures provide about similar figures? How are these ratios helpful in solving problems?

Students extend their notions of similarity of triangles from previous Investigations to similarity of parallelograms (including rectangles). Specifically, the ratios of adjacent sides of parallelograms are emphasized since parallelograms have at most two different pairs of congruent angles and two different side lengths.

By comparing their ideas about similar triangles to other similar figures, such as parallelograms, students deepen their understanding of similarity. For example, two parallelograms can have congruent corresponding angles but not be similar. This is not true for triangles.
Display Teaching Aid 4.1A: Girl with Fish or use the pictures in the Student Edition. Tell the class the images were formed on a computer.

• How do you think the computer produced these variations of the original shape? (Answers may vary. Possible answer: The left image was stretched vertically. The middle image was reduced vertically. The right image was reduced both horizontally and vertically.)
  • Think of these images in the same way you thought of the Wumps. Which ones would be in the same family as the original? How do you know? (The image on the right, because she has the same shape as the original. The figure on the left is too tall and thin. The figure in the middle is too short and wide.)
  • Which figures are similar? (The image on the right appears to be similar to the original figure.)
  • The Wumps had straight sides to measure. These figures do not. What can you measure instead? (You can measure each figure’s height and width.)
Display the following table from Teaching Aid 4.1A: Girl with Fish.

• What patterns do you notice about these measures? (Some students might compare the height of one figure to the height of another, and the width of one figure to the width of another. This comparison gives the scale factor. Some students might notice that each measurement of the original figure is twice the corresponding measurement of the figure on the right.) (Language)

Fill in the last column of the table with the ratio written in fraction form. Tell the class that, just as you can talk about equivalent fractions, you can talk about equivalent ratios. In this example, the height-to-width ratio of the original figure is equivalent to the height-to-width ratio of the image on the right. In this Investigation, students will find that if corresponding ratios are not equivalent, the figures cannot be similar.
Mathematics Note: The connection between fractions and ratios is complex.

You can write a ratio in fraction notation. For example, you might have 1 green marble for every 2 white marbles. This can be written 1:2, which can be written ½ . ½ as a fraction means 1 part out of two totals in the whole, whereas this ½ as a ratio does not imply anything about total. It is a part-to-part ratio.

Another difference between fractions and ratios is putting together amounts. When adding fractions, we get equal size pieces in the whole (denominator) and add the number of pieces (numerators). For example, 1/2 + 1/2 = 2/2. If we combine two ratios, we can add to both the quantities. For example, if we have a box of 1 green for every 2 white and another box of 1 green for every 2 white, we get 2 green for every 4 white. Or, 1/2 and 1/2 as a ratio could mean 2/4. Many times, we combine ratios to find equivalent ratios.

Students often do not understand all of the subtleties between fractions and ratios. For this reason, when you write ratios in fraction form, it is helpful for students to label the two quantities from the ratio. For example,
10 cm tall/8 cm wide = 5 cm tall/4 cm wide
In this animation, a robot finds a device that takes his picture. The robot distorts the photo in a few different ways. The robot wonders which of the distortions is similar to the original picture.

Tell students that, in this Problem, they will look at sets of quadrilaterals and triangles to determine if they are similar. They will use scale factors and ratios of adjacent sides to determine similarity.

Pass out Learning Aid 4.1A Rectangles Sets 1-3 and Learning Aid 4.1C Ratio Recording Sheet for the initial Challenge. Distribute Learning Aid 4.1B Triangles Sets 4-7 for students to use during What If Situation A.

Implementation Notes: You might want to assign one group of parallelograms and one group of triangles to some groups and have other groups do the rest. The focus of this Problem is on internal ratios – ratio of two adjacent sides in one figure being equivalent to the two corresponding adjacent sides in the other similar figure. For quadrilaterals suggest they use short to long side as the ratio. Then ask in the Summary about long side to short. Both produce equal ratios, but the order of the ratio needs to be consistent.

As you circulate, check to make sure that students are writing correct ratios for each rectangle and for each parallelogram. You can hand out copies of Learning Aid 4.1D: Ratio Recording Sheet (Agency, Identity, Ownership) if your students would benefit from using a table to organize their work. Provide any necessary help in keeping track of the place of corresponding measures in the ratios. The numerators of each ratio need to relate corresponding lengths, and the denominators of each ratio need to relate corresponding lengths.

Students should label their work in some way, such as length to width or width to length. Students need to be consistent in what they consider to be the width or length in terms of which one is the long side, and which one is the short side on rectangles and parallelograms.

• Can finding two corresponding angles help? (This can help students with orientation of the shapes and to find adjacent sides.)
  • Can finding corresponding side lengths help? (Yes. This will help them create the ratios.)
  • How do you know that you have the correct numbers in the numerator and the denominator of your ratio for the triangles? (Possible answers: I labeled the sides “long side,” “short side,” and “middle side” for each triangle to be sure that my numerators represent corresponding sides, and my denominators represent corresponding sides; or I color-coded the sides so that corresponding sides are the same color; or, for each triangle, I wrote the following ratio: short to long, and then I filled the ratio in with the correct side lengths.) (Language)
  • Can you form different ratios than the ones you have been recording? (Yes, each ratio can be rewritten so that its numerator and denominator are swapped. If each ratio is changed in this way, the ratios will still compare corresponding sides.)
  • How do these two ratios compare? (They are reciprocals of each other.)
What evidence will you use in the Summary to clarify and deepen understanding of the Now What Do You Know? What will you do if you do not have evidence?

How does the ratio of adjacent side lengths with in two similar figures compare to the ratio of corresponding side lengths across two similar figures? How are these ratios helpful in solving problems?
Look for students making sense of using ratios and connecting this reasoning with their understanding of scale factors.

Discuss which figures were similar in the Initial Challenge. Be sure that students’ ratios name corresponding side lengths in the numerators of the ratios, and that they name corresponding side lengths in the denominators of the ratios.
Students should compare the ratios for both similar and non-similar figures. This is an opportunity to review or assess their understanding of equivalent fractions.

• Are all rectangles similar? (No. The corresponding angles are all 90 degrees, but the corresponding ratios are not equal, and a scale factor doesn’t exist.)
  • How are rectangles different from other parallelograms? (90-degree angles)
  • We used ratios of short side to long side on the quadrilaterals. What if we had used long side to short side, would this still give us the same answers on which ones are similar? (Yes)
  • Can you draw two nonrectangular parallelograms that have equal corresponding angle measures but are not similar? (One way to show this is to draw a parallelogram and then lengthen a pair of sides to form the other parallelogram. The angles remain congruent, but the side lengths of two sides have changed while the other two side lengths have not changed.)

• Why is it necessary to check angle measures in nonrectangular parallelograms, but not in rectangles? (Two parallelograms can have corresponding adjacent sides that are in the same ratio but have angle measures that are different. We found out in Shapes and Designs that we might have two sides with lengths of 5 and two sides with lengths of 10, for example, that form a parallelogram. This parallelogram can have angles of any size. For similarity, corresponding angles must be congruent. Rectangles always have congruent angle measures, however. A rectangle always has four 90° angles.)
  • Describe the criteria that are necessary for two parallelograms to be similar. (Parallelograms must have congruent corresponding angle measures. Also, the corresponding ratios of adjacent sides must be equal. Note that instead of mentioning ratios, students might suggest that scale factors between shapes must be the consistent for all sets of corresponding sides. Both criteria for side lengths are correct.)

Focus a conversation about the ratio of the height of one shape to the height of a similar shape or the ratio of the width of one shape to the width of a similar shape. These ratios give the scale factor from one figure to another. (Language)

• What are the ratios of shortest side to longest side for each of the similar triangles you chose? (Possible answer: For Triangle C: 6/12; for Triangle D: 10/20)
  • What do you notice about those ratios? (Possible answer: The longest-side to shortest-side ratios for Triangles C and D are both equal to 1/2, or 0.5.)
  • What is the scale factor from the smaller triangle to the larger triangle? (Answer for Triangles C and D: 12/3)
  • How does the scale factor relate to the proportions of the ratios of adjacent sides? (Possible answer: 10 = 6 x 12/3 and 20 = 12 x 12/3, or (6 x 12/3 ) ÷ (12 x 12/3 ) = 10/20 )

Pick a pair of similar triangles from the Student Edition, and ask students to sketch two more triangles that are similar to them. They should provide side-length measurements. Have them check the ratios of the side lengths to ensure that the triangles are, in fact, similar.
Note: Some students may conjecture that for triangles to be similar, we only need to check corresponding angle measures
Look at the set of triangles. Only two angle measures are given.
• How can you find the missing angle measure? (The sum of the angle measures in a triangle is 180°. We can use this fact to find the missing angle.)

Students might claim that Triangle A and Triangle B are similar because, for each triangle, the difference between the long side and the middle side is 1 meter. Additionally, the difference between the middle side and the short side is 3 meters for each triangle. This is a common mistake that students make, and it may be mentioned in your class. If it is not, you might consider stating this in the form of a student conjecture:

• George thought Triangle B was similar to Triangle A. Why might he be thinking this? (The difference between the long side and the middle side is 1 meter, and the difference between the middle side and the short side is 3 meters for each triangle.)
  • What would you tell George in order to explain why he is incorrect? (One reason why these triangles are not similar is because their angles are different.)
Have a discussion about the What If questions. Focus the conversation on scale factors and internal ratios.

• Choose a pair of similar figures. What is the scale factor? (Answers will vary depending on the pair chosen.)
  • How did you find the scale factor? (Answers will vary. Students will talk about matching corresponding sides and using division to find the scale factor.)
  • How does the method you used to find scale factor relate to the ratio of corresponding sides in two similar figures? (Answers will vary. One example follows.
Darnell: Rectangles B and C are similar with a scale factor of 1.5 from B to C.
Darnell: I looked at the corresponding sides. Then I looked at what would multiply by 6 to get 9. It was 1.5. Then I use that scale factor with 10 and it got the corresponding side length of 15.
Teacher: How does this relate to the ratio of corresponding side lengths.
Darnell: 9/6 is a ratio that relates the corresponding short sides of Rectangles C and B. When you divide 9 by 6 you get the scale factor of 1.5. The same is true for the long sides 15/10.
Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know questions.
Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.
• What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know?

1. Where did my students get stuck?
  2. What strategies did they use?
  3. What breakthroughs did my students have today?

• How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?
  • Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this Unit? The next Unit?

In this Problem, students use shadows and mirror reflections to estimate the heights of real objects that are difficult to measure directly. They collect relevant pieces of data in order to make the estimate. They also discuss the accuracy of these estimated heights and point out problems that might arise from these methods. The shadow method in Problem 4.3 needs to be done outside on a sunny day.
If it is not sunny or you do not have the resources to complete this Problem outside, you can use an alternative method of measuring inaccessible heights or lengths using a picture.
Students recognize that the mathematics they have learned so far in this Unit is helpful for solving problems in real life.

The parallel lines of the rays can be used to show that the corresponding angles are equal. This was done in Shapes and Designs. In the Shapes Unit students find that they can only draw one (unique) triangle given three angle measures. This means that if two triangles have corresponding angles equal, then the figures are congruent and hence similar. Sun and shadows always produce similar triangles.

Mathematics Note: We have only used adjacent sides because we are dealing with are triangles and rectangles. The sides being compared do not have to be adjacent if we are working with other figures. For example, in a hexagon the ratio of any two sides will work as long as the ratio of the same corresponding side lengths in the other hexagon work.
If two figures are similar, how can you use information about the figures to find unknown lengths, perimeters, areas, or angle measures?
Explore the use of similarity to solve real world problems. Use understanding of similar figures, including scale factors and ratios, to find a distance that is difficult to measure.
Understand that ratios of corresponding adjacent side lengths within two similar figures are equal

• use scale factor and/or ratio relationships between corresponding side lengths to determine if two figures are similar
  • use understanding of scale factor and/or ratios of adjacent sides to find missing lengths, perimeter, and area
If needed you can begin this Problem by having students practice one or two missing-part problems such as the one below, also displayed in Teaching Aid 4.2: Sample Missing Triangle Length.
In this example, a = 2.4 in. (You can use a scale factor of 0.75 from the larger triangle to the smaller triangle.)

Explain that, for this Problem, students need to find a pretty good estimate for the height of a tower, a building, a pole, etc., but there is not any way to measure it directly. They are tasked with finding out how they can use mathematics to estimate such measurements.

If it is a sunny day begin with the shadow method and find the height of the school building, tree or other large object. If it isn’t a sunny day you can begin with the mirror method in the Initial Challenge followed by the Statue of Liberty example of the shadow method in What If Situation A and the camera distances in What If Situation B.

• Today is a sunny day, and we are going to use the sun to help us estimate heights that we are interested in measuring. When the sun shines on objects, the objects cast shadows. From your experiences, what can you say about the shadows that the sun casts? (Students may note that the length of the shadow depends on the height of the object. They may also note that shadows for all objects change length as the sun moves during the day. Shadows are longer when the sun is near the horizon, whether in the morning or evening, and very short in the middle of the day when the sun is more directly overhead. They may mention that shadows are cast in the same direction for all objects.)
  • Let’s think about the relationship between the length of a shadow and the height of an object. At the same time of day, how will the shadows of two objects that have different heights compare? (The shadow of the taller object will be longer.)
  • This means that the length of the shadow depends on the height of the object. Imagine that you are looking at a tall pole when the sun casts a shadow for the pole. In your mind, move around the pole until you can see both the pole and its shadow from the side. Sketch what you think this would look like. (Make sure the students envision the two legs of the right triangle made by the pole and the shadow.) (Portrayal)
  • Who would like to share their sketch with the class? (A sample sketch is shown below)

• What do you think? Is your sketch somewhat like this one? (Allow students to describe any important similarities or differences between their sketches and the displayed sketch.)
  • Draw a dashed line on your sketch to show a triangle formed by the pole, the shadow, and the line from the top of the pole to the tip of the shadow. (It is not important that students draw this sketch completely correctly at this stage. This activity is to increase interest in the setting and to get students to visualize the scene.)
Suppose you took a meter stick outside and held it perpendicular to the ground. You can picture an imaginary line (the ray of the sun) from the top of the meter stick to the ground.

• Can you picture a triangle formed by the meter stick, the ray of the sun, and the shadow? (Sketch a picture of the triangle.)
  • If there is another nearby object, such as a flagpole or a tree, what do you think will be true about that object, its shadow, and the ray of the sun? Will they form a triangle? Is the triangle similar to the one formed by our meter stick? Explain your reasoning. (At this stage, some students may understand that the two triangles are similar. They might be able to prove this by considering the interior angles of the triangles. Others might continue to feel that sides should be measured and compared before they are sure the triangles are similar.)

• How can you use this meter stick and the sun to find out how tall our school is? What measurements do you need to take? (Students can describe using similar triangles consisting of the objects (the school and the meter stick), their shadows, and the sun’s rays to determine the height of the school. They need to find the measurements of both shadows and the meter stick.)
In order to reinforce the importance of checking angles, you might hold the meter stick at an obtuse angle to the ground and stick:

• Can I hold the meter stick this way and use the resulting shadow length to find the height of the building? Why or why not? (No, the school’s wall is perpendicular to the ground, so the meter stick must also be perpendicular.)
  • The parallel lines of the rays can be used to show that the corresponding angles are equal. This was done in Shapes and Designs. You could choose to tell them that sun and shadows always produce similar triangles.

Pass out materials and Learning Aid 4.2: Statue of Liberty Diagram. Have students now begin the Problem in groups of 2-4. (If you prefer not to do the experiment you can tell the students that the length of the stick is 3 feet, and its shadow is 2 feet. The length of the shadow of the statue is 74 feet.)

Some students do not have many opportunities to make actual measurements of distances larger than a desktop. If this is true of your students, some groups may need help in getting started. One of the important goals of this Problem is to give students these measuring experiences, as well as experience using similarity to solve a real-world problem. Be prepared to assist students in their measuring. As you are monitoring their progress, ask students to estimate what they are measuring to gauge the reasonableness of their answers.

Describe how similar figures can be used to find missing measurements of objects that cannot be measured directly. Is there another method? Explain.
Collect the students’ data and display a line plot of their estimates. Discuss the patterns of the various data entries and possible sources of error.

The parallel lines of the rays can be used to show that the corresponding angles are equal. This was done in Shapes and Designs. In the Shapes Unit students find that they can only draw one (unique) triangle given three angle measures. This means that if two triangles have corresponding angles equal, then the figures are congruent and hence similar. Or you could choose to tell them that sun and shadows always produce similar triangles.
We could push this fact here or just remind students that the two triangles are similar. That is if corresponding angles of two triangles are congruent/equal, then the triangles are similar.

• What is a typical unit of measure to describe the height of the building (or other object you choose) based on the class data? Why? (Possible answer. Meters: They are big enough that we won’t have huge numbers recorded, but small enough that we will have an answer larger than 1.)
  • Who can describe to the class exactly how your group used similar triangles to estimate the measure of the building? (Answers will vary. Students can reference the sketches they drew. Bring out the vocabulary of scale factors and/or ratios.)
  • Can you always use this method to estimate the height of an object? Why or why not? (Yes, the method always works because facts about similar triangles do not change. However, if it is not sunny out, a different method must be used.)
  • Why does each angle of the large triangle have the same measure as the corresponding angle of the small triangle? (The statue is at a right angle to the ground, so we are careful to hold the stick at a right angle to the ground, too. Another angle is the angle formed by the sun and the ground. For two nearby points at a common time, the sun appears at the same angle, making these corresponding angles congruent. Finally, the third angle must be the same in each triangle since all three interior angles of a triangle must add to 180°.)
  • What does this suggest about the similarity of the triangles? (Because all of the angles of the two triangles are congruent, the triangles are similar.)
  • When using the shadow method, what problems might affect the accuracy of your answer? (Answers will vary.)

You want to have groups share different strategies, including internal ratios of adjacent sides, scale factor, and ratios of corresponding sides across the figures. (Agency, Identity, Ownership)
• How did you decide which one was the imposter? (Answers will vary. Connect the strategies.)
Example conversation from one classroom discussing the rectangles:
Teacher: How did you decide which rectangle was the imposter?
Jackson: We decided that there isn’t one. Since all the angles are 90° they are all similar.
Teacher: Does everyone agree with Jackson’s group?

Noemi: No. That is only true for squares because since you start with all sides being the same when it is scaled up all sides will scale up the same but with non-square rectangles that isn’t the case.
Jackson: So, which one is the imposter.
Noemi: We think the small rectangle is the imposter.
Jackson: But it looks like the other two. It is a rectangle.

Noemi: We said that at first too. But then we looked for a scale factor and found that there is 1.5 from the medium to large rectangle and when we tried to find a scale factor from the small to either the medium or large it didn’t work.

Bobbe: We did what Noemi’s group did. From the small to medium–the short sides grew 2 times as much and the long sides 3 times as much so there isn’t a scale factor. From small to larger the short sides grew 3 times as much and the long sides 4.5 times as much, so they don’t have a scale factor either. (Bobbe shows this in a drawing.)
Jackson: I see it now. I agree.
Teacher: Did anyone think about it another way?

Carter: We used ratios. The ratio of the short side to long side in the medium and large rectangle are equivalent and the small rectangle is not. This also proves that they are similar, and that the small rectangle is the imposter.
